Although differences exist across models in the nature of mechanisms that support performance, we expect that research that attempts to train these features of performance will be highly beneficial. Researchers who have exploited techniques that increase awareness and/or exploration of task-relevant options (e.g., option awareness training, crystal ball technique, decision skills training), for instance, by having participants engage in mental simulation as a means to assess the value of generated options (e.g., G. A. Klein, 1997), have demonstrated the efficacy of these kinds of approaches for improving skilled performance across several domains (also see Cohen et al., 1998; G. L. Klein et al., 2011). However, we would go one step further and suggest that when training also requires participants to anticipate the future state of the situation, more specific development would occur of the types of situational mechanisms that support performance (Ward et al., 2008; Ward et al., 2009).

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: In sum, data collected across three experiments in soccer indicated that although all participants generated few options, on average skilled participants predicted more accurately the outcome of the situation and generated more task-relevant and fewer task-irrelevant options than did less-skilled participants. The observed positive relationship between the number/prioritization of task-relevant options generated and anticipation accuracy together with the verbal report data suggest that skilled prediction was more consistent with the use of an LTWM-based situational representation rather than of simpler heuristics, such as TTF or RPD.

The data have important implications for how future experts should be trained. To improve skilled prediction, apprehension, and performance, trainees should engage in training that increases awareness and exploration of relevant options and that allows them to assess the value of generated options, for instance, via mental simulation. Furthermore, when such training requires participants to predict the outcome of a broad range of challenging situations, we propose that more specific development would occur of the types of situational mechanisms that support performance. Future theories of expert skill need to be able to describe the range of mechanisms that account for superior prediction and decision making across a range of contexts. In addition, they need to be able to account for how these mechanisms are developed through training and practice. It is important that theories of expert skill should be able to predict when the use of the proposed mechanisms will result in superior performance such that training can be tailored appropriately.

bio.p: Paul Ward is professor of psychology and head of Centre for Sports Science and Human Performance at University of Greenwich, Chatham Maritime, UK. He received his PhD in applied experimental psychology from Liverpool John Moores University, UK. His research is focused on understanding the cognitive systems that support expertise in complex domains such as sport, law enforcement, and health care, and on improving performance through training and technological design.

K. Anders Ericsson is Conradi Eminent Scholar and professor of psychology at Florida State University in Tallahassee, FL. He is a fellow of the American Psychological Society, and of the American Psychological Association and a member of the Swedish Royal Academy of Engineering Sciences. He received his BA and PhD in psychology at the University of Stockholm, Sweden. His latest books are The Cambridge Handbook of Expertise and Expert Performance and Development of Professional Expertise.

A. Mark Williams is professor and head of sports science at Brunel University, London, UK. He completed a PhD in human movement science at the University of Liverpool in 1995 and has published extensively in the areas related to skill acquisition, expert performance, perceptual-cognitive expertise, and visual perception.
